review.title: Toward a Taxonomy and Computational Models of Abnormalities in Images
review.abstract: The human visual system can spot an abnormal image, and reason about what makes it strange. This task has not received enough attention in computer vision. In this paper we study various types of atypicalities in images in a more comprehensive way than has been done before. We propose a new dataset of abnormal images showing a wide range of atypicalities. We design human subject experiments to discover a coarse taxonomy of the reasons for abnormality. Our experiments reveal three major categories of abnormality: object-centric, scene-centric, and contextual. Based on this taxonomy, we propose a comprehensive computational model that can predict all different types of abnormality in images and outperform prior arts in abnormality recognition.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: The mechanisms underlying the formation of human categories are the subject of many competing accounts, including those based on prototypes (Minda and Smith 2001), examples (Nosofsky 1984), density estimation (Ashby and Alfonso-Reese 1995), and Bayesian Inference (Goodman et al. 2008). But all modern models agree that the representations of human categories involve subjective variations in the typicity or probability of objects within categories. For example, the bird category includes both highly typical examples and extremely atypical examples such as penguins and ostriches, which, while belonging to the category, are subjectively "abnormal" examples. Visual images can appear abnormal by having features that differ in some way from what is typical of the categories to which they belong. In this paper, we ask what makes visual images appear abnormal in relation to their obvious categories, something that human observers can judge, but it is difficult to grasp.

sections.heading: Computational Framework
sections.text: In this section, we propose a mathematical model to find and judge abnormal images, based on three scores derived from three main groups of abnormalities. We begin by examining normal images and propose a model to relate elements of an image: object, context, and scene. Next, we derive a series of scores, called "surprise scores," to measure how abnormal an image is in relation to these elements. Later, we explain how we merge the different scores to determine whether the image is abnormal or not, and finally find the dominant reason for abnormality that influences this decision.

sections.heading: Parametric Model for Typicality
sections.text: For the final decision on the abnormality of an image, we should compare the three surprise values and select the maximum as the main reason for the abnormality. However, there are two problems that prevent us from using the maximum of raw surprise values. These surprise values described are based on the quantification of the information content, so these measurements are unlimited (since the probability is near zero, the surprise is approaching infinity); the other problem is that these surprise values are not comparable, since the information content is modulated differently in each of them. Consequently, it is difficult to compare the values of SurpriseO, SurpriseS and SurpriseC to determine which of these reasons leads to the abnormality in the image, if any. To address these problems, we propose to model the distribution of the surprise values for normal images. To achieve this goal, we compare the adaptation of different parametric models to the empirical distribution of three surprise values, which are calculated over the normal images.

sections.text: We train our model for predicting abnormalities on six classes of objects: airplane, boat, car, chair, motorcycle and sofa. We select these categories to be comparable to related works (Saleh, Farhadi and Elgammal 2013). sections.heading: Context-centric Typicality Modeling
sections.text: To determine the typical position of objects in images and their relative size, we use PASCAL context datasets (Mottaghi et al. 2014) that comment on PASCAL images with semantic segmentation. To this end, we divide PASCAL images into grids of equal size and calculate for each grid the probability of the number of pixels belonging to each object category. We learn these distributions over all images designated as positive examples of the object category. Our experiments show that the ratio of the pixels contributing to a particular object in a grid follows an exponential distribution.

sections.heading: Scene-centric Typicality Modeling
sections.text: To model the typical scene and context, we use the annotation of the SUN dataset (Xiao et al. 2010) to find the most common scene categories for our six object classes. We start with the top ten scene categories for each object class and merge them based on similarities in images, resulting in 4,700 scene categories aged 16. sections.heading: Conclusion & Future Work
sections.text: In this work, we approached the challenging research question: What makes an image look abnormal? We compiled the largest set of abnormal images and conducted a large-scale experiment with human subjects to investigate how people think about abnormal images. We proposed a varied list of abnormality reasons from human reactions and inferred a taxonomy of visual cues that make an image abnormal. Based on three main components of this taxonomy, we created computer vision models that can detect abnormal images and justified this decision with three surprise values. Delving deeper into the categories of derived taxonomy is an important work in the future. Recognition: This research was supported by the NSF Prize IIS-1218872.
